title:  "LLMNR Attack"
type: docs
---

## #What is LLMNR**(Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution) ?**   
   
- LLMNR (Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution) is a fallback mechanism used in Windows when the DNS (Domain Name System) fails to resolve a hostname. It allows devices to resolve hostnames in a local network using multicast queries.   
   
   
## #How Does LLMNR Works?   
   
1Ô∏è‚É£ **A device needs to resolve a hostname**   
‚Äá‚Äá- When a Windows machine wants to connect to another system (e.g., `fileserver.local`), it first **queries its configured DNS server**.   
‚Äá‚Äá- If DNS **fails** to resolve the hostname, the system falls back to **LLMNR**.   
2Ô∏è‚É£ **The system sends an LLMNR multicast query**   
‚Äá‚Äá- The device **broadcasts a request** over UDP port **5355** asking:   
‚Äá‚Äá    üëâ "*Who has the IP address for fileserver.local?"   
‚Äá‚Äá- This query is sent to **all devices** in the local network.   
3Ô∏è‚É£ **A device with that hostname responds**   
‚Äá‚Äá- If a system in the network has the hostname **fileserver.local**, it replies with:   
‚Äá‚Äá    üëâ "*I am fileserver.local, and my IP is 192.168.1.10."   
‚Äá‚Äá- The requesting machine then **connects to that IP address**.   
4Ô∏è‚É£ **If no response, it falls back to NBT-NS**   
‚Äá‚Äá- If LLMNR also **fails**, the system tries **NetBIOS Name Service (NBT-NS) on UDP 137** as a last resort.   
   
## #Why LLMNR Is Vulnerable ?   
   
‚Äá‚Äá- **LLMNR (Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution) is a multicast protocol that operates on UDP port 5355.**   
‚Äá‚Äá- **It follows a "First Come, First Serve" principle**, meaning it accepts the first response it receives **without verification**.   
‚Äá‚Äá- **When a system queries "Who has fileserver.local?"**, it blindly trusts the first device that responds.   
‚Äá‚Äá- **If an attacker replies first**, the victim's machine will attempt to connect to the attacker's provided IP, sending its **username and NTLMv2 hash** if authentication is required.   
   
**LLMNR/NBT-NS only works with hostnames**, not direct IP addresses.   
   
```
[SMB] NTLMv2-SSP Client   : fe80::a3f2:5ec8:da22:a818
[SMB] NTLMv2-SSP Username : TONYSTARK\peaterparker
[SMB] NTLMv2-SSP Hash     : peaterparker::TONYSTARK:5dbced5cd8ee4cb3:5B044E2F75A8822373280AE8DC7D0D59:

```
